location_details: Incident at the GRC-TUR border section, involving alleged pushback from Greece to Turkey.
context_note: Human Resources informs TR media reported possible push back incidents at the Turkish Greek Land border. According to Evrensel Gazetesi, Greek police reportedly beat up two Pakistani refugees and confiscated their money and belongings before forcibly deporting them to Turkey. The incident involves allegations on so called 'pushback' of 2 persons by the Hellenic police to the border with Turkey without taking into consideration their personal circumstances. Such police action may amount to collective expulsion, which Article 19 of the EU Charter explicitly prohibits. Furthermore, in the course of aforementioned police actions, it is clear that the persons subjected to these actions did not have access to an effective remedy when transferred to the border with Turkey. Frontex emphasizes the importance of conducting an efficient investigation in incidents involving violations of fundamental rights. Frontex recommends that the investigative procedure should be conducted in full compliance with the principles of impartiality, objectivity and confidentiality.
evidence_quote: Greek police reportedly beat up two Pakistani refugees and confiscated their money and belongings before forcibly deporting them to Turkey.

location_details: n/a
uncertainty_note: The exact point of the incident is not specified, only the general border area between Croatia and Bosnia.
context_note: Migrant interviewed in Vidin reported physical abuse and violence by Croatian border guards after crossing the border. Allegations include beating with batons, confiscation of valuables, separation of children from mothers, and forced return to the Bosnian side of the border (pushback). Interviewee also reported witnessing drownings. Previous attempts involved similar treatment. Incidents in Usivak Camp (Bosnia) with Bosnian Police also mentioned.
evidence_quote: Migrant informed FX about potential violation of human rights in HRV and BHI. FRO considers that the alleged facts could amount to serious breaches of the right to life, integrity, asylum, human dignity, the prohibition of torture and inhuman and degrading treatment, and of collective expulsion.

location_details: n/a
context_note: An interview was performed with a male migrant apprehended in Vidin, who showed clear signs of physical abuse and violence. He claimed these injuries were from Croatian border guards. He reported multiple unsuccessful attempts to cross the border. During one attempt, a group of migrants (around thirty) was stopped by Croatian officers who beat them with police batons, confiscated valuables (phones), and left them standing for hours. They were then put into a truck, taken to a forest, and beaten again upon disembarking. The interviewee's friend allegedly suffered a dislocated shoulder. Previous attempts involved similar routes, with migrants being robbed, humiliated, and beaten, and children separated from mothers. The interviewee also claimed to have seen migrants drown in a river while trying to escape police brutality. FRO considers these allegations could amount to serious breaches of the right to life, integrity, asylum, human dignity, the prohibition of torture and inhuman and degrading treatment, and collective expulsion, as well as a lack of access to an effective remedy.
evidence_quote: Croatian border guards stop them and steal from them. After crossing the border with a group of migrants (around thirty), using the off line map application, they were stopped by seven/eight Croatian officers, who after a few words started to beat them with police batons.

location_details: Bulgaria,, Bulgaria
where_clear: Near the Greece-Bulgaria border, in Bulgaria, close to a village and an old train station.
location_text_raw: Bulgaria,, Bulgaria; village, close to GRC-BGR borders; forest (in BGR); open place near the GRC border; old train station
uncertainty_note: Specific village name and coordinates are redacted.
context_note: On 12.09.2019, at [redacted] in [redacted] village, close to GRC-BGR borders, HP officers from [redacted] apprehended twenty six (26) irregular migrants. All of them declared as victims of threats, beating, dog biting, robbery and violent deportation from BGR to GRC, from the side of the Bulgarian authorities. They were naked, wearing only their underwear. An irregular migrant speaking for the group stated they were apprehended by BGR police in a forest, beaten by officers and bitten by police dogs. They were forced to walk, then taken by car to a police station for body and luggage search. They were then driven to an open place near the GRC border around 5:00 A.M. They were asked for money, and when none was given, they were forced to take off their clothes and humiliated. BGR officers searched clothes and bags, took all phones, beat them with batons, burned belongings, and told them to go straight to Greece. The migrants followed orders, went into a ditch, and eventually reached an old train station in Greece. Hellenic Police provided clothes, water, and food to the apprehended migrants. Frontex team members deployed in the operational area (neither in GRC nor in BGR) were not involved in this case and had no contact with any migrants on the relevant dates.
evidence_quote: Declared as victims of threats, beating, dog biting, robbery and violent deportation from BGR to GRC, from the side of the Bulgarian authorities. ii) Were naked, wearing only their underwear.

location_details: Lesvos
uncertainty_note: Latitude and Longitude are 0.000000, indicating placeholder values. Location is specified as Lesvos, which is an island.
context_note: A complaint was forwarded to Human Resources regarding a cultural mediator's alleged improper behaviour from November 2019 to January 2020 on Lesvos. The mediator was accused of humiliating migrants, taking copies of travel documents with a mobile phone, and searching bags. Legal provisions allegedly violated include the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights (Article 8(2) on personal data, Article 4 on torture/inhuman treatment) and Frontex Code of Conduct (Article 10 on Behavioural Standards). The cultural mediator was suspended from future Frontex deployments following conversations, and a final report was produced on 15.04.2021.
evidence_quote: The alleged improper behaviour of the cultural mediator concerned was observed while interacting with migrants performing alleged actions of humiliation, taking copies of migrant's travel documents with a mobile phone, searching the migrants' bags, etc.

location_details: The incident occurred in the Evros area, involving multiple pushbacks across a border river. Specific location within the operational area is redacted.
where_clear: Evros area, border river between Greece and Turkey
location_text_raw: Text Removed - Operational Area, Evros area
uncertainty_note: Specific location within Evros area is redacted.
context_note: An interviewee reported two incidents in the Evros area. On November 7th, 2018, after landing, he and other migrants were attacked, forced back across the river, stripped, beaten, and robbed of valuables. On November 10th, 2018, after crossing the river again, he and others were intercepted, beaten, robbed, forced to undress, and pushed back. The interviewee was apprehended on November 14th, 2018, and interviewed on November 16th, 2018. He did not wish to file a complaint and provided limited details, possibly due to fear, and there were doubts about translation accuracy.
evidence_quote: the interviewee stated that he was pushed back, assaulted, treated inhumanly and robbed... forced to go back through the river after their valuables were taken away, after the men were stripped naked and after they were beaten.

location_details: Incident occurred in Serbia, near the border with Bulgaria, involving migrants who had crossed from North Macedonia. The migrants were forced to cross into Bulgaria twice and were eventually apprehended in Bulgarian territory.
location_text_raw: at the [redacted] Bulgaria, Serbia from North Macedonia, border with Bulgaria, Bulgarian territory
uncertainty_note: Specific location within the border area is redacted or not provided, and the migrant could not recognize the exact location on a map.
context_note: A group of five migrants, after crossing into Serbia from North Macedonia, was stopped twice by Serbian police on 23 and 24 December 2023. Allegations include ill-treatment (beating, punching, kicking, gunpoint), destruction of mobile phones, theft of money (at least 200 EUR), and forced collective expulsion to Bulgaria. The migrants were eventually apprehended by Bulgarian authorities. Serbian authorities denied the allegations, stating no record of such incidents.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office concludes as likely that a group of five migrants was apprehended by the Serbian police in Serbia, and subsequently forced to cross the border to Bulgaria. The Office was unable to independently corroborate the alleged theft and ill-treatment but considers possible, that the group was subjected to ill-treatment.

context_note: On 06/04/2017, at approx. [redacted] Greek time one temporary housing container caught fire. Two migrants, both of them Iraqi males (Age: 22, 23) were apprehended after the incident due to suspicion of arson, and the fire was put out. The container was completely destroyed after the fire. No persons were injured during the incident. No FX staff were present at the hotspot during the incident. HP informs that the above mentioned apprehended persons are detained at Police Premises. The police is investigating the incident. They expect to have both suspects examined by a psychologist today. Head of [redacted] is kindly being requested to inform the [redacted] on the island about such incidents as quickly as possible in the future, as they could have impact on FX activities. There is no more available info. Nothing else to report.
evidence_quote: On 06/04/2017, at approx. [redacted] Greek time one temporary housing container caught fire.

location_details: A group of migrants was apprehended by Serbian Border Police officers near a train station in Serbia, close to the Serbian-Bulgarian border, and subsequently forced to cross the border to Bulgaria by a river in a small forest. The incident occurred at the Serbian-Bulgarian border area.
location_text_raw: Bulgaria, a migrant alleged ill-treatment, theft, and collective expulsion to Bulgaria by Serbian Border Police officers. According to the report, on 31/12/2023 the group of migrants was stopped by a border police vehicle with two officers close to a [redacted] that later was joined by another two vehicles and three border police officers. Allegedly, the border police officers took the migrants' phones, money, and food, and forced them into the cars. After a short ride, upon reaching the border with Bulgaria by the river, they ordered the migrants to cross the border. According to the report, before crossing the border, the migrants were beaten by Serbian Border Police officers.
uncertainty_note: Specific locations within the border area (e.g., train station, river) are redacted.
context_note: The incident involved Border Police officers of Serbia (participants of JO Serbia Land 2023). The Fundamental Rights Office notes that Serbian authorities denied the allegations and an internal investigation found no wrongdoing, but the Office considers the allegations possible/likely based on migrant testimony and observed injuries.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office concludes as likely that a group of migrants was apprehended in Serbia by the Serbian Border Police, and subsequently forced to cross the border to Bulgaria. The Office was unable to independently corroborate the alleged theft and ill-treatment, but further considers possible, that the group was subjected to ill-treatment.

context_note: An unofficial refoulement from Greece to Turkey took place along the Evros River on May 24th. It concerns Turkish citizens seeking asylum in Greece, including a journalist, Murat Çapan, who was previously sentenced in Turkey. A family of six, including an infant, and three men were handed over by Greek police to masked gunmen. The Hellenic League for Human Rights (HLHR) has evidence and is bringing the matter to UN High Commissioner for Refugees and Greek courts.
evidence_quote: An unofficial refoulement from Greece to Turkey took place along the Evros River on May 24th. This time, it concerns Turkish citizens seeking asylum in Greece, among them Murat Çapan, who was a journalist... were handed over by Greek police to a group of masked gunmen.

Hellenic authorities denied any maltreatment reports for the specified dates. FRO concluded that alleged facts could amount to serious breaches of fundamental rights but lacked sufficient corroborating evidence from Hellenic authorities to confirm or refute.
evidence_quote: Minor migrant allegedly hit with baton by Greek Police officer

location_details: hotspot Text removed - Operational Area
uncertainty_note: Specific hotspot name is redacted.
context_note: A violent unrest triggered approximately at [redacted] when Hellenic Police was about to apprehend a Haitian migrant. A group of migrants, with African origin, attempted to release the Haitian national. Episodes escalated, with approximately three hundred (300) participants, mostly African origin. Stones were thrown, and fires were set in bins and containers. Two fires were clearly visible near the EASO and detention areas. Hotspot was ordered to be evacuated. Hellenic Police restored public order. Fires were extinguished. A tent was burnt, a container destroyed. Garbage containers were set on fire. Firefighters vehicle windscreen was smashed. Four office containers (used by NGOs) were totally burnt. Some big tents and smaller tents, garbage bins were burnt. Four containers destroyed, two tents, three containers damaged, eight metal waste bins damaged. Registration area (Frontex containers, RIC, HP and Europol) not affected. EASO coordinator confirmed they are not going to resume work 11/07/2017 or even for a longer period. Registration of new arrivals performed as usual.
evidence_quote: A violent unrest triggered approximately at [redacted] when Hellenic Police was about to apprehend a Haitian migrant in order to be handed over the 2nd negative reply, regarding the asylum process.

location_details: Incidents occurred at the Lithuanian border where 15 migrants were detected in Lithuanian territory and subsequently directed from the territory. Lithuanian authorities applied preventive measures to 8 persons and 7 persons separately, directing them from the territory of Lithuania.
location_text_raw: Lithuanian territory, at the border signal
context_note: The SIR concerns incidents on 13 January 2022 where Lithuanian authorities applied 'preventive measures' to 15 migrants (8 and 7 persons in two separate incidents) who had crossed into Lithuanian territory, directing them back from the territory. This practice is linked to a new national border management procedure from August 2021, which prevents asylum seekers from being admitted if they cross outside designated border crossing points. The Fundamental Rights Officer assesses these actions as likely violating several fundamental rights, including the right to asylum, prohibition of collective expulsion, non-refoulement, and right to life and human dignity, due to lack of individual assessment and effective access to asylum procedures, and the risk of chain-refoulement.
evidence_quote: On 13 January 2022 preventive measures were applied to 8 persons, and they were directed from the territory of Lithuania... On 13 January 2022, the preventive measures were applied to 7 persons, and they were directed from the territory of Lithuania.

location_details: Three underage migrants died of hypothermia approximately 20 km from the Bulgarian-Turkish border, on Bulgarian territory. Alerts were received for Position 1 (42°15'43"N 27°19'56"E), Position 2 (42°17'00"N 27°19'36"E), and Position 3 (42°17'54"N 27°19'37"E). Bodies were found near these positions (22m, 8m, and 4km deviation respectively).
where_clear: Near the Bulgarian-Turkish border, on Bulgarian territory
location_text_raw: approximately 20 km from the Bulgarian-Turkish border; Position 1 at 42°15'43"N 27°19'56"E; Position 2 at 42°17'00″N 27°19'36"E; Position 3 at 42°17'54"N 27°19'37"E
uncertainty_note: Bodies were found near the reported alert positions, with deviations of 22m, 8m, and 4km respectively.
context_note: Three underage migrants died of hypothermia near the Bulgarian-Turkish border after crossing from Türkiye. NGOs alerted Bulgarian emergency services multiple times with precise locations, but authorities allegedly failed to react and actively obstructed NGO rescue attempts, leading to significant delays in reaching the migrants. The Fundamental Rights Office concluded that Bulgarian authorities failed to assist and rescue migrants, violating the right to life and child protection obligations.
evidence_quote: According to a report published by two NGOs, three underage migrants died of hypothermia on 27/12/2024 approximately 20 km from the Bulgarian-Turkish border after they had crossed illegally from Türkiye. Allegedly, the Bulgarian authorities not only did not react to the alerts, but also actively obstructed the NGOs' rescue attempts which resulted in a more than 24-hour delay in reaching the reported positions where the migrants' bodies were found.

location_details: Alleged irregular return of migrants from Bulgaria to Greece. Migrants initially crossed Türkiye-Greece border near Edirne, then allegedly apprehended in Bulgaria and pushed back to Greece. Later apprehended by Hellenic police in Greece. Exact locations of apprehension and pushback are disputed and unclear.
location_text_raw: irregular return of migrants from Bulgaria to Greece, Bulgaria-Greece border area
uncertainty_note: The exact location of the alleged apprehension and pushback is highly disputed between migrant testimony, Hellenic authorities, and Bulgarian authorities. The Fundamental Rights Office could not confirm the migrant's presence in Bulgarian territory. Many details are redacted.
context_note: On 24/01/2025, the Fundamental Rights Office received information about an alleged irregular return of 8 migrants from Bulgaria to Greece, conducted by masked police officers. Migrants were allegedly body-searched, had belongings confiscated, loaded into a police vehicle, driven, released, and commanded to walk towards Greece. They were later apprehended by Hellenic Police in Greece. The Fundamental Rights Office could not independently verify the incident. Migrant's testimony is not corroborated by Bulgarian authorities or other evidence. Bulgarian authorities deny any apprehension in their territory, while Hellenic authorities reported migrants crossed from Bulgaria to Greece. The Office notes similarities with a previous SIR (13800/2022) involving alleged pushbacks by Bulgarian border police.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office was not able to independently verify that the incident happened as alleged by the migrant. The migrant's testimony, supported by the account from the Hellenic authorities, is not corroborated by the information provided by the Bulgarian authorities nor by any other available evidence.

Equipment of NGOs and UNHCR was damaged, and an Anti-Riot Unit intervened to restore order. No Frontex staff were involved, and no injuries were reported.
evidence_quote: On 19.11.2017 at approx. [redacted] a protest took place in RIC [redacted]. The riot started close to the minors Section and it was provoked by few Arabic speaking migrants. There are damages of the equipment of some NGOs and UNHCR. The outside window of FX [redacted] container is broken. The Anti-Riot Unit of the HP intervened in order to re-establish the public order. At about [redacted] this morning the protest stopped. At the moment the situation is calm. No Frontex staff was involved in the incident. No information about injured people during the incident.

where_clear: Joint Return Operation from Greece to Georgia and Pakistan
location_text_raw: The Joint Return Operation to Pakistan and Georgia organized by Greece was implemented final destinations Georgia and Pakistan. A Frontex Representative onboard Aircraft, deployed in the Operational Area, was the first person to receive the information that triggered this SIR. During the operations on the ground, the presence of staff equipped with cameras, was noticed.
uncertainty_note: The incident concerns a media leak from a Joint Return Operation spanning multiple countries (Greece, Georgia, Pakistan), involving activities both on the ground and onboard aircraft. The precise location where the pictures were taken or the leak originated is not specified.
context_note: The incident involves pictures from a Joint Return Operation (JRO) reaching media outlets. Frontex team members wearing Frontex vests were visible in the pictures without blurred faces. The presence of staff with cameras was noticed during ground operations, and their presence was approved locally as observers. The SIR was triggered when a Frontex Representative onboard an aircraft was informed of the online articles.
evidence_quote: RET Division ascertained the presence in open sources/media outlets of pictures from the ongoing Joint Return Operation GEO&PAK by GR showing Frontex Team's members, wearing Frontex vests, without blurred faces, during the boarding

All 12 persons were brought to the hospital by the ambulance. ... Three (3) bodies brought to Thessaloniki hospital for the autopsy.

location_details: Alleged Evros River
where_clear: Evros River border between Greece and Turkey
context_note: A Turkish news magazine article alleged that 4 irregular migrants, including one woman, were captured and beaten by Greek police at the Evros River border and subsequently pushed back to Turkey in a boat. A medical check reportedly confirmed they had been battered. Frontex's assessment notes that the article lacks concrete date/location details and doesn't mention Frontex assets. Photos and video accompanying the article show a boat with 5 persons but no clear signs of law enforcement or violence.
evidence_quote: Irregulars in Edirne, illegally crossing over to Greece, were captured and beaten at the border by the Greek police, and then sent back to Turkey in a boat.

location_text_raw: Tunisian SAR zone and later in the Maltese SAR zone
country_or_area: Tunisian SAR zone, Maltese SAR zone
geocodable_query: Tunisian SAR zone, Maltese SAR zone
context_note: More than approximately 17 hours passed from the moment the migrant boat was sighted adrift for the first time (24/01/2022 at 06.54 UTC) by Frontex until it was rescued (24/01/2022 at 23.50 UTC). The Fundamental Rights Office underlines that search and rescue at sea requires prompt coordination and assistance from all parties involved to ensure the protection of migrants' right to life and to avoid, as much as possible, loss of life. While the Frontex aerial asset contributed with the detection and updates on the boat in distress which were communicated to the competent MRCC authorities, the Fundamental Rights Office underlines that a more efficient and prompt SAR response and coordination, particularly between the two MRCCs in whose search and rescue zones the boat was detected, would have been necessary, considering in particular that 7 migrants died while on board.
evidence_quote: A boat adrift was detected by a Frontex Surveillance Aircraft detected in the Tunisian SAR zone and later in the Maltese SAR zone with 280 + persons on board. The migrant boat was eventually rescued by the Italian authorities. During the rescue operations 7 people on board were found dead.

where_clear: Migrant boat detected in Tunisian SAR zone, then Maltese SAR zone, eventually rescued in Italian SAR region.

uncertainty_note: Specific coordinates are redacted.
context_note: A migrant boat with 280+ persons was detected adrift in Tunisian and Maltese SAR zones. Rescue took over 17 hours, resulting in 7 deaths. FRO notes the need for prompt SAR coordination.
evidence_quote: A boat adrift was detected by a Frontex Surveillance Aircraft detected in the Tunisian SAR zone and later in the Maltese SAR zone with 280 + persons on board. The migrant boat was eventually rescued by the Italian authorities. During the rescue operations 7 people on board were found dead.

location_details: Samos Island
context_note: Migrants (approx. 130) arrived in 3 boats, screened at Text Removed - Reporting Tools premises due to closed hotspot. An attempt to transport them to the camp failed because a group of Africans started a fire. Another large group of migrants descended from the camp to Vathy town to protest bad living conditions at the reception centre, heading towards Text Removed - Reporting Tools premises for registration, escorted by Text Removed - Reporting Tools. The situation in Samos Island hotspot was deteriorating with potential conflicts. By 19:00 LT in Vathy and 20:00 LT in the Samos hotspot, the situation returned to normal. Migrants were transported to the hotspot, and fingerprinting activities began.
evidence_quote: Currently Text Removed - Reporting Tools is screening the migrants who arrived in 3 boats (approx. 130 migrants) from the previous days in the premises of Text Removed - Reporting Tools due to closed hotspot. After the migrants from 1st boat were fully screened, Text Removed - Reporting Tools tried to transport them to the camp, but unfortunately they had to return because a group of Africans started fire once again when they saw the transportation van.

location_details: Apprehension and mistreatment by Serbian police occurred in Serbia, near the border with Bulgaria, after migrants crossed from Bulgaria. The migrants were then forced to return to Bulgaria.
location_text_raw: forest close to the Serbia-Bulgaria border
context_note: Two migrants, after crossing from Bulgaria to Serbia, were apprehended by Serbian police on 12/01/2024. They were allegedly physically mistreated, had their belongings confiscated, were forced to remove clothes, and then informally returned to Bulgaria. The Fundamental Rights Office (FRO) considers it likely that these events occurred, despite Serbian authorities denying any registered incident and suggesting injuries could be from smugglers. The FRO recommends independent investigations and improved monitoring.
evidence_quote: The Office considers likely that two persons were apprehended by the Serbian police, physically ill-treated, that their personal belongings and clothes were removed and that they were informally returned to Bulgaria.

location_details: Incident occurred at the Kybartai Border Crossing Point in Lithuania, where a person arriving from the Russian Federation was refused entry despite expressing a wish for asylum.
context_note: A national arriving from the Russian Federation at the Kybartai Border Crossing Point in Lithuania on 19/02/2025 requested asylum orally and in writing but was refused entry. The person was turned back to the Russian Federation. The Regional Administrative Court later annulled the refusal of entry decision, stating the person clearly expressed a wish for asylum and that SBGS officers failed to register the application or take appropriate actions. The Fundamental Rights Office concluded that the right to asylum was violated.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office received information about an incident when a person reportedly asking for asylum at the [REDACTED] Lithuania was refused entry.

location_details: The Miskar gas platform is registered under the flag of Tunisia, with Tunisian registration (Maritime Mobile Service Identity is 672700000). The platform is situated in the Gulf of Gabès, approximately 75 NM off the Tunisian coast, and is operated by BG Group and Entreprise Tunisienne d'Activités Pétrolières (ETAP), Tunisia's national oil and gas company. It is a fully manned installation, accommodating up to 24-person offshore crew, highly equipped gas facility designed for offshore processing, compression, and export. The platform is located in international waters within overlapping Tunisian and Maltese search and rescue regions.
where_clear: Miskar gas platform in overlapping Maltese and Tunisian SAR regions, Gulf of Gabès
location_text_raw: Libyan search and rescue region, Miskar gas platform in Maltese and Tunisian search and rescue regions (the two countries' search and rescue regions overlap in this area), Gulf of Gabès, approximately 75 NM off the Tunisian coast
country_or_area: Tunisia (Miskar gas platform), Maltese and Tunisian SAR regions, Libyan SAR region
geocodable_query: Miskar gas platform, Gulf of Gabès, Tunisia
context_note: On 01/03/2025, a migrant boat was detected by Frontex in Libyan SAR, then reached the Miskar gas platform in overlapping Maltese and Tunisian SAR regions. 32 people were stranded on the platform for four days. Despite regular updates to MRCCs, no rescue was coordinated. On 04/03/2025, NGO Sea-Watch rescued 32 people, reporting one casualty. The SIR investigates the delay in rescue.
evidence_quote: On 04/03/2025, the NGO's Sea-Watch rescue vessel Aurora in coordination with the Tunisian authorities rescued 32 people from the Miskar gas platform and reported one casualty.

context_note: During patrol activity in Alexandroupolis, Greece, a crew member slid off stairs while attempting to take a towing rubber boat and injured their right knee. Medical examination suggested stretched ligaments.
evidence_quote: one of the crew members, while attempting to take a towing rubber boat, slid off the stairs and injured his right leg knee.

context_note: During patrol activity on 20th of February 2020, one of the crew members, while attempting to take a towing rubber boat, slid off the stairs and injured his right leg knee. In the morning, the knee was swollen and an x-ray was taken during the hospital examination and nothing was broken, but according to the doctor, there was a possibility that the ligaments had stretched. A more detailed diagnosis would be given after 7 days of rest and cooling of the knee.

context_note: Migrant entered Albania irregularly, was apprehended by Albanian police, fingerprinted, detained overnight, and then pushed back to Greece from an abandoned area near a BCP.
evidence_quote: On the 5 February 2022, after entering irregularly the Albanian territory via [redacted] area, the migrant was travelling alone towards this area. Around [redacted] on that day the Albanian police found him and brought him to a service car. Afterwards he was escorted to the detention centre [redacted] indicated by the migrant), where he spent the night. On the same day, on 5 February 2022, the Albanian authorities took his fingerprints, as well as a profile picture, and the migrant filled and signed some forms. The next day, around [redacted] in the morning, the Albanian authorities brought them to an abandoned area [redacted] (the migrant pointed the exact location on a map) 5 minutes' walk close to the BCP, and then pushed him back to Greece.

location_details: Port area of Mytilini, Lesvos, and Mantamados area, Greece
uncertainty_note: Specific location details removed, but Mytilini and Mantamados area mentioned in context.
context_note: Violent protests and demonstrations occurred in Mytilini, Lesvos, Greece, against the disembarkation of anti-riot police and the building of a 'Multifunctional Control Centre'. A Frontex patrol was blocked by demonstrators, and their vehicle was damaged. No injuries to Frontex personnel were reported. Clashes between police and locals also occurred in Mantamados area.
evidence_quote: Demonstrators were shouting and one of the demonstrators was kicking the right and the front of the Text Removed - Justification 6 broke a mirror of the Text Removed - Justification 6.

location_details: Lesvos, Greece
uncertainty_note: Specific location details (latitude/longitude) were redacted.
context_note: During the night violent protests occurred in the port area of Mytilini when anti- riot Police tried to disembark the ferry from the mainland. Civilians tried to prevent the Anti- Riot Police to disembark. Teargas has been used. At this moment (25/02 11:00 LT) a peaceful demonstration of approx. 200-300 local people is taking place at the centre of Mytilini, Lesvos. The demonstration is against building the 'Multifunctional Control Centre' (MCC). There were also protests at Karava area during the night. This morning two Text Removed - Justification 2 crew were travelling with Text Removed - Justification 6 from Mytilini to the north of Lesvos. The road was blocked by approx. 30 demonstrators and HP Anti-Riot Police. One of the Text Removed - Justification 2 went out of the car in order to ask the HP Anti-Riot Police if they could continue their way. This was denied and they had to return. On the way back to the Text Removed - Justification 6 the Text Removed - Justification 2 was pushed at his back by one of the demonstrators and the situation was escalating. Demonstrators were shouting and one of the demonstrators was kicking the right and the front of the Text Removed - Justification 6 broke a mirror of the Text Removed - Justification 6. The right door of Text Removed - Justification 6 is damaged, no further damages. Text Removed - Justification 2 were not injured. Text Removed - Justification 3 just informed FX that there are major clashes between police forces and locals at Mantamados area. The roads are closed and the area should be avoided.
evidence_quote: Riot in Lesvos - FRONTEX patrol blocked by the demonstrators... Demonstrators were shouting and one of the demonstrators was kicking the right and the front of the Text Removed - Justification 6 broke a mirror of the Text Removed - Justification 6.

location_details: Frankfurt Airport, Germany, involving transit from Cuba/Serbia and Venezuela/Turkey.
context_note: This SIR details two incidents at Frankfurt Airport in October and November 2022 where Cuban and Venezuelan nationals, despite explicitly requesting international protection/asylum, were denied access to the asylum procedure by German Federal Police and subsequently returned to their countries of origin. The Fundamental Rights Office found that border guards were involved in assessing the substance of asylum claims, a task requiring specialist expertise, and highlighted the need for effective access to asylum procedures and procedural safeguards.
evidence_quote: In the cases under scrutiny, the Fundamental Rights Office observed that the persons concerned were interviewed by members of the Federal Police and although they explicitly requested access to the asylum procedure, were denied such by the German Federal Police based on their findings that they had not identified fear of political persecution and claims were not sufficiently consistent.

location_details: Bulgaria, within the JO Terra 2022 operational area, involving incidents at accommodation, a gas station, and a supermarket.

context_note: A report concerning inappropriate behavior and Code of Conduct violations by a Standing Corps officer (BGO 3) deployed in JO Terra 2022 in Bulgaria. Incidents include offensive behavior towards colleagues, consuming alcohol in uniform, and driving under the influence of alcohol on February 1st and 9th, 2022. The operational team proposed terminating deployment.
evidence_quote: Taking into account all the clear facts stating that BGO 3 multiple times violated the principles of Code of Conduct, behaving in a way to compromise the prestige and the nature of his mission, as well as he brought discredit to [redacted] Home MS and Frontex, the Operational team propose to start the process of terminating [redacted] deployment immediately.

context_note: Two SC Officers deployed in JO Bulgaria Land 2024 did not report for duty on 2024-02-10 after being denied recuperation days. They were unreachable by communication channels. After sustained efforts, it was established they had left the operational area without reporting. This was considered a breach of duty and a violation of the Code of Conduct.
evidence_quote: SC Officers did not report for duty and left the OA without informing chain of command.

location_details: On the Belarusian side of the border, approximately 60 m from the border with Lithuania, near BCP Šalčininkai.

context_note: Five individuals (two females, two males, one minor) from Sudan and Kenya reportedly sought asylum at BCP Šalčininkai, Lithuania, but were denied entry and turned back to Belarus. The child among them later developed fever and pain. The Fundamental Rights Office finds it likely that access to asylum was denied and the right to an effective remedy was violated, citing lack of proper documentation and video evidence.
evidence_quote: The local officers allegedly ignored the asylum requests and turned the group back to Belarus.

location_details: Surroundings of Vial camp, Chios, Greece
context_note: Two Frontex personnel were involved in an incident near Vial camp in Chios, Greece, where demonstrators intercepted and damaged their rental car (broken mirrors). The officers were not physically harmed.
evidence_quote: crowd intercepted their vehicle and started damaging the rental car (at least both mirrors are broken).

context_note: Today, at about 19:45 hours, after the registration process in the Vial camp was over, 2 Team Members were involved in an incident, allegedly with locals. After attempting to leave the camp through the normal access, they had to return back due to demonstrations. During their second attempt to leave the area, in the surroundings of the camp, crowd intercepted their vehicle and started damaging the rental car (at least both mirrors are broken). After this incident, they managed to turn the car around and return back to Vial camp, where they remain to this point. The rest of the damages in the car still need to be assessed. Local Hellenic Police coordinator met with the affected TMS and provides all necessary support. None of the officers reported to suffer from any physical harm, yet they are affected by the incident.
evidence_quote: crowd intercepted their vehicle and started damaging the rental car (at least both mirrors are broken).

location_details: Apprehension by a joint Polish-Latvian patrol at the border of Latvia and Belarus. The person was identified, checked for health, provided with food, and then ordered to return to the country of departure (Belarus) based on a Ministerial Order related to an emergency situation.
location_text_raw: at the border of Latvia and Belarus
uncertainty_note: Exact location along the border is redacted.
context_note: A person was apprehended by a joint Polish-Latvian patrol at the Latvia-Belarus border. The person was identified, checked for health, provided with food, and then ordered to return to the country of departure (Belarus) based on a Ministerial Order related to an emergency situation. The report highlights potential violations of fundamental rights, including the right to asylum and non-refoulement, due to the lack of individual assessment and effective access to asylum procedures.
evidence_quote: The migrant was intercepted inside the territory of Latvia. However, the Latvian authorities ordered the person to return to the territory of the country of departure. The event could be classified as potential violation of EU or international law, in particular, related to fundamental rights and international protections obligations.

location_details: Wooded area near the T-junction Riha- Ujmohacs- Sarhat
context_note: Apprehension of a group of migrants by Hungarian Police and Frontex. A juvenile migrant (allegedly 14-18 years old) from the group, claiming Serbian nationality and showing a Serbian refugee camp document, requested to remain in Hungary and be brought to a refugee camp. Hungarian authorities stated no special treatment is foreseen for people of this age. An internal investigation was initiated by Hungarian authorities to clarify possible lack of rule of law regarding the treatment of juveniles/UAMs, as Hungarian regulations differentiate procedures for juveniles (14-18) and UAMs (below 14).
evidence_quote: At the moment to move the group to another assembly point, the juvenile migrant asked to Hungarian Police Officers to allow him to remain in Hungary and to be brought in a Hungarian refugee's camp. Hungarian counterpart stated no special treatment is foreseen for people with this age.

location_details: Frontex surveillance aircraft sighted a migrant boat in pursuit by three Tunisian Garde Nationale patrol boats in the Tunisian and Libyan search and rescue regions. The boat was initially sighted 26 NM from the shore of Tunisia, and later its position was updated to 28 NM from the shore of Tunisia, 5 NM north from the previous position.

context_note: Tunisian Garde Nationale patrol boats pursued an overcrowded migrant boat, performing dangerous manoeuvres including ramming and riding over its rear, endangering the lives of more than 25 people on board. One migrant was mistreated by crew members after transfer to a patrol boat. Frontex surveillance aircraft observed the incident.
evidence_quote: Frontex surveillance aircraft sighted three Tunisian Garde Nationale patrol boats in pursuit of an overcrowded migrant boat in the Tunisian and Libyan search and rescue regions (the two countries' search and rescue regions overlap in this area).

location_details: The incident occurred near the Albania-Montenegro border, close to the railway track, approximately at specific coordinates (redacted in the document). The terrain is described as mountainous and covered with shrubs, accessible only on foot. The location is also near a main road, contradicting Albanian authorities' claims of a non-vehicle-accessible, mountainous area.
where_clear: Albania-Montenegro border area near railway track

context_note: This report details an incident where two migrants were allegedly robbed by individuals in Albanian police uniforms near the Albania-Montenegro border. The Fundamental Rights Office assesses it as likely that a robbery occurred, noting similarities with other incidents in the area, suggesting a pattern of exploitation. Albanian authorities' investigation did not confirm police involvement and provided a misleading location description, raising concerns about its accuracy. The Office recommends a thorough investigation by Albanian authorities and measures to prevent future incidents.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office received information from Frontex operational staff about two migrants allegedly robbed by two perpetrators in Albanian police uniforms on 16/05/2025.

context_note: An individual involved in the RA FOA Return 2025 operation unexpectedly informed the service of their return to their home country, which had an extremely negative impact on operational requirements. An inquiry revealed issues with communication and informing the Chain of Command. The incident was assessed as a violation of Art. 10 (Behavior standards) of the Code of Conduct (SIR Category 2) and also met requirements for SIR Category 3 due to its impact on Frontex operational activities and image. No further actions will be taken against the individual, and the case is closed.
evidence_quote: unexpectedly informed the service at that and returned to home country. had an extremely negative impact to the operational requirements. concludes that art. 10 (Behavior standards) of Code of Conduct applicable to all people participation in Frontex activities was violated.

location_details: The incident occurred near the Albania-Montenegro border, specifically in a specific area in North-western Albania. Similar incidents have occurred in the same area, within an approximate range of 2.5 kilometers, at locations coinciding with where other incidents described in relevant SIRs took place.
where_clear: Near the Albania-Montenegro border, North-western Albania
context_note: Three migrants were allegedly robbed by two perpetrators wearing Albanian police uniforms on 22/05/2025 near the Albania-Montenegro border. They were threatened with arrest and deportation to Greece if they did not hand over their money. The migrants were forced to hand over 220 euros. After taking their money, the alleged officers allowed the migrants to proceed, providing guidance on how to cross the border into Montenegro and avoid the border crossing point.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office received information from Frontex about three migrants allegedly robbed by two perpetrators wearing Albanian police uniforms on 22/05/2025. According to the migrants, the group was stopped by the alleged police officers near the Albania-Montenegro border.

location_details: Location of the incident: Text Removed - Justification 3. Hospitalization at the Military Hospital in Sofia, Bulgaria.
where_clear: Redacted location, hospitalization in Sofia, Bulgaria
uncertainty_note: Specific incident location is redacted, but hospitalization is in Sofia.
context_note: On 18.03.2020 around 14:30 one Text Removed - Justification 4 deployed in Text Removed - Justification 3 has been hospitalized at the Military Hospital in Sofia. According to the doctor, he presented compatible symptoms with Covid-19 such as difficulties while breathing. Two days ago he felt some pain in his chest and lungs. He received immediate medical assistance but no further measures were considered necessary. Nevertheless, this morning he had some problems with his breathing and went to the urgency services to be checked. He was sent to the Military Hospital in Sofia for additional medical checks. On 20.03.2020 around 10:30, Text Removed - Justification 4 was informed that Covid-19 test gave a NEGATIVE result. At 13:30 Text Removed - Justification 4 left the Military Hospital and he was sent to his accommodation in Sofia. The Covid-19 testing has been done. location_details: Six migrants illegally crossed the border from Belarus to Latvia and were intercepted by Frontex officers and Latvian Border Guards. They were subsequently redirected to Belarus without individual assessment, based on Latvian Order No. 518/10.08.2021.
context_note: The incident involved the interception and redirection of six migrants from Latvia back to Belarus by Latvian Border Guards, with Frontex officers present, under a state of emergency order (Cabinet of Ministers Order No.518/10.08.2021) that allowed for redirection without individual assessment. The Fundamental Rights Office assessed this action as potentially amounting to serious breaches of fundamental rights obligations, including collective expulsion, denial of asylum rights, and non-refoulement, due to the lack of individual assessment and the risk of 'chain-refoulement' to Belarus.
evidence_quote: Six migrants were redirected to Belarus without individual assessment in application of paragraph no.4 from the Cabinet of Ministers Order No.518/10.08.2021

location_details: The incident involved a group of 20 nationals, including the interviewee, who were detained in Serbia, transferred to the Serbia-Bulgaria border, and then allegedly subjected to ill-treatment and forced return near Pirot, Serbia, and subsequently crossed into Bulgaria.
where_clear: Serbia-Bulgaria border area, near Pirot, Serbia
context_note: A group of 20 nationals, including the interviewee, was detained in Serbia. On 15/02/2024, they were allegedly transferred to the Serbia-Bulgaria border, where Serbian police confiscated belongings, forced them to remove clothes, and ordered them to cross to Bulgaria. The interviewee was later apprehended near Pirot on 16/02/2024, allegedly physically mistreated (beaten on feet with a baton, resulting in bruises and swelling) and informally returned to Bulgaria. The Fundamental Rights Office could not establish with certainty that the incidents occurred as alleged, and Serbian authorities denied the incidents.
evidence_quote: During a screening interview performed by Frontex, a screened person stated that a group of 20 nationals, including himself, was detained for ten days in Serbia. After that, on 15/02/2024 the group was allegedly transferred to the Serbia-Bulgaria border, where the Serbian police confiscated their belongings, forced them to remove their clothes, and ordered them to cross to Bulgaria.

location_details: A group of 20 nationals was detained for ten days in Serbia. On 15/02/2024, they were allegedly transferred to the Serbia-Bulgaria border, where Serbian police confiscated belongings, forced them to remove clothes, and ordered them to cross to Bulgaria. Due to disorientation, the interviewee reached Pirot, Serbia, where he was apprehended on 16/02/2024, physically mistreated, and forced to return to Bulgaria. The migrant had bruises and swelling on feet and knees.
where_clear: Serbia-Bulgaria border area, including a detention center in Belgrade, Pirot, and a border crossing point
geocodable_query: Serbia-Bulgaria border area, including Belgrade and Pirot
context_note: The Office however notes that this incident was enquired against the backdrop of a total of 25 independent allegations of violent collective expulsions by the Serbian authorities that were reported to the Office since December 2023, with which pattern the allegations in the present SIR align. This trend raises important concerns about migrants' rights being violated at Serbia's border with Bulgaria.
evidence_quote: Despite relative credibility of the migrant's statements, the Office considers it unclear whether on 15/02/2024 the Serbian police confiscated the belongings of a group of 20 persons, forced them to remove their clothes, and ordered them to return to Bulgaria. It is equally unclear whether on 16/02/2024 the interviewee was apprehended by the Serbian police, physically ill-treated, and informally returned to Bulgaria.

location_details: Information from an NGO about a migrant boat in distress south of Lesvos in Greek territorial waters. NGO posted additional coordinates (38.887833, 26.446500). Turkish Coast Guard rescue records indicate 10:55 am LT off the coast of İzmir's Karaburun district. NGO later published a more detailed version stating the boat was in distress 'deep inside Greek waters, southeast of Plomari, Lesvos south' at first light on 19/02/2024, 8.35 km distance from the shoreline of Lesvos. Greek authorities reported two incidents at 38° 48' 00" N 026° 26' 18" E and 38° 46' 24" N, 026° 26' 18" E, both 'Lesvos island inside Turkish TTW'.
location_text_raw: south of Lesvos in Greek territorial waters
uncertainty_note: Multiple coordinates provided by different sources (NGO, Greek authorities) with slight variations. The exact point of the alleged incident is not definitively confirmed, but the general area is consistent.
context_note: The Fundamental Rights Office established that Frontex encountered the migrant boat but could not verify the timeline of events preceding the rescue by the Turkish Coast Guard. The alleged modus operandi (engine destruction, towing to Turkish waters) is consistent with previously highlighted practices of the Hellenic Coast Guard. Concerns were raised about incomplete Frontex operational reporting and insufficient cooperation from Greek authorities. Recommendations were made to both Frontex and Greek authorities to improve reporting, safeguards, and investigation of fundamental rights violations.
evidence_quote: Based on the available information, the Fundamental Rights Office has established that Frontex encountered the migrant boat in question and considers likely that this encounter happened in the morning hours of 19/02/2024

location_details: Information from an NGO about a migrant boat in distress south of Lesvos, in Greek territorial waters. NGO provided coordinates 38.887833, 26.446500. Turkish Coast Guard rescued migrants off the coast of İzmir's Karaburun district. Greek authorities reported two incidents with approximately 50 migrants each, at positions 38° 48' 00" N 026° 26' 18" E and 38° 46' 24" N, 026° 26' 18" E, in the sea area Lesvos island inside Turkish TTW. The NGO later claimed the boat was in distress 'deep inside Greek waters, southeast of Plomari, Lesvos south', 8.35 km from Lesvos shoreline. Frontex confirmed its vessel encountered the migrant boat in the area of Lesvos.
where_clear: South of Lesvos, near Greek-Turkish maritime border, Aegean Sea.
location_text_raw: south of Lesvos in Greek territorial waters, 38.887833, 26.446500
country_or_area: Aegean Sea, Lesvos, Greek-Turkish maritime border, Turkey
uncertainty_note: The exact location of the alleged incident is described with multiple coordinates and textual descriptions, some of which are slightly different but all point to the same general area in the Aegean Sea near Lesvos and the Greek-Turkish maritime border. The rescue by Turkish Coast Guard occurred in Turkish waters, further complicating the precise incident location.
context_note: An NGO reported a migrant boat in distress with approximately 50 migrants on board. Videos showed a blue patrol vessel and a black inflatable boat in the vicinity. Frontex identified its vessel (a Bulgarian asset) as the one in the videos and confirmed an encounter with the migrant boat. The NGO alleged that a Hellenic Coast Guard vessel towed the migrant boat to Turkish waters, destroyed its engine, and confiscated phones. Frontex noted that the alleged modus operandi is consistent with practices highlighted in previous SIRs involving the Hellenic Coast Guard. Greek authorities denied the allegations and refused to provide detailed responses. Frontex noted reporting gaps from its own staff.
evidence_quote: On 19/02/2024, the Fundamental Rights Office received information from an NGO about a migrant boat in distress south of Lesvos along with videos taken by the migrants. The videos showed a blue patrol vessel in the vicinity and a seemingly black inflatable boat with two persons on board close to the migrant boat. The Fundamental Rights Office identified the migrant group in photographs taken during a rescue by the Turkish Coast Guard on 19/02/2024.

location_details: Andalusia, Spain. Migrants screened in Almeria. Alleged beating in San Jose (Almeria).
context_note: 5 Algerian migrants arrived in Spain by boat. Two presented visible signs of violence during screening in Almeria. One had a bruise around his left eye, no explanation given. The second reported being beaten by Guardia Civil personnel in San Jose (Almeria), showing dry blood on face/ears and difficulty walking. The migrant refused to file a complaint. FRO considers the alleged facts could amount to serious breaches of fundamental rights and degrading treatment, but also notes that the information provided by Spanish authorities was not sufficient to corroborate or refute the allegations, leading to the recommendation for closure of the SIR.
evidence_quote: The second one (he could barely walk and had dry blood on his face and ears) reported to be beaten by Guardia Civil personnel in San Jose (Almeria);

location_details: Migrants screened in Almeria; one migrant reported being beaten by Guardia Civil in San Jose (Almeria).
geocodable_query: Almeria, Spain; San Jose, Almeria, Spain
context_note: On 25 March 2021, 5 Algerian migrants arrived in Spain by boat. During screening in Almeria by Frontex staff, two showed signs of violence. One migrant had a bruise around his left eye without explanation. The second migrant, who could barely walk and had dry blood on his face and ears, reported being beaten by Guardia Civil personnel in San Jose (Almeria). The migrant refused to file a complaint. The Fundamental Rights Office (FRO) initiated an inquiry. Spanish authorities launched an internal investigation, reporting that two migrants were aggressive, one self-harmed, and they denied medical assistance. FRO found the Spanish authorities' information insufficient to corroborate or refute the allegations and recommended SIR closure, while emphasizing potential risks of such incidents and the importance of proper investigation and effective remedies.
evidence_quote: The second migrant (who could barely walk and had dry blood on his face, and ears) reported to be beaten by the Guardia Civil personnel in San Jose (Almeria).

location_details: A Border Crossing Point (BCP) in Bulgaria, within the JO Terra 2022 operational area.
uncertainty_note: Specific BCP is redacted.
context_note: A Frontex SC Officer reported an incident involving a missing child at a Bulgarian BCP. The Fundamental Rights Office found a flawed assessment of the child's best interests, prioritizing basic needs over security concerns, which led to the child's escape with the father during a second-line check. The report also notes the use of warning shots and 'stop cartridges' by border guards to prevent the escape, deemed necessary and proportionate by FRO.
evidence_quote: As regards the case scrutinised under SIR 11009/2022, the Fundamental Rights Office found that a flawed assessment of best interests of a child reported missing by Bulgarian border guards, one that prioritised basic needs over security concerns, laid the foundation for certain actions to be taken and for certain failure to act creating an environment in which the interests of the child were not safeguarded and the escape of a father with said child during second line check was rendered possible.

location_details: A group of 22 migrants landed on Lesvos, Greece. The group was later apprehended, forced onto a boat, transferred to a bigger boat, sailed towards Türkiye, put in a life raft and abandoned adrift. Rescued by Turkish Coast Guard in Turkish territorial waters, South-East of Lesvos island, at approx. location 38°54′06″N, 26°47'36"E.
where_clear: Lesvos Island, Greece and Turkish territorial waters near Lesvos.
country_or_area: Greece, Türkiye (Lesvos Island, Turkish territorial waters)
context_note: The Fundamental Rights Office established that 17 migrants were ill-treated, subjected to theft of property, and ultimately pushed back to Türkiye by the Hellenic Coast Guard and/or individuals acting in concert and coordination with the Greek authorities. This conclusion was reached based on multiple and mutually coherent victim and witness testimonies, supported by a body of further evidence.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office established beyond doubt that 17 migrants of nationality (possibly one ) were rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard from a drifting life raft on 17/02/2023 at 14:25 LT, at approx. location 38°54′06″N, 26°47'36"E in Turkish territorial waters, South-East of Lesvos island.

location_details: A group of 22 migrants landed on Lesvos, Greece. 17 migrants were apprehended and forced onto a boat in Lesvos, transferred to a bigger boat, sailed towards Türkiye, put in a life raft and abandoned adrift. They were rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard off Izmir province, Dikili district, at approximate location 38°54′06″N, 26°47'36"E in Turkish territorial waters, South-East of Lesvos island.
where_clear: Lesvos Island, Greece and Turkish territorial waters near Izmir province, Dikili district
location_text_raw: Lesvos, Türkiye, Izmir province, Dikili district, 38°54′06″N, 26°47'36"E
context_note: A group of 22 migrants landed on Lesvos. 5 were registered, while 17, including women and children, were apprehended by masked men, searched, had belongings confiscated, and were forced onto boats. They were transferred to a larger vessel, abandoned in a life raft in Turkish waters, and rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard. The Fundamental Rights Office concluded that the 17 migrants were ill-treated, subjected to theft, and pushed back by Greek officials or individuals acting in coordination with them.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office established that the 17 migrants were ill-treated, subjected to theft of property, and ultimately pushed back to Türkiye by the Hellenic Coast Guard and/or individuals acting in concert and coordination with the Greek authorities.

location_details: A migrant group sailed from the Turkish coast towards Samos, Greece. Near Samos coast, the boat was intercepted by a Hellenic Coast Guard vessel, towed back to Turkish territorial water, and migrants were abandoned. They were later rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard off Izmir province Menderes district.

evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office was unable to independently establish the veracity of allegations relating to the migrant's attempt to reach Samos on 12/11/2022.

The group was loaded onto a Hellenic Coast Guard vessel, sailed towards Turkey, and abandoned in two life rafts off Canakkale province, Ayvacik district. They were later rescued by the Turkish Coast Guard.

The Fundamental Rights Office believes the migrant's account is relatively credible and that these actions, if verified, would constitute prohibited collective expulsion and a threat to life.

location_details: Migrants were transported from a reception centre in Serbia (south of Belgrade, possibly Obrenovac or Bogovadja Asylum Centre) to a shallow river near the Serbian-Bulgarian border, after passing Dimitrovgrad. They were then forced to cross the river into Bulgarian territory.
location_text_raw: shallow river, what migrants assumed to be by the border with Bulgaria
uncertainty_note: The exact river is not named, but its location relative to Dimitrovgrad and the border is described.
context_note: The Fundamental Rights Office concludes that a group of ten migrants was likely subjected to collective expulsion from Serbia to Bulgaria. Allegations of ill-treatment and seizure of property could not be independently corroborated but are considered possible. Serbian authorities denied the allegations based on internal checks, but the FRO regrets that questions regarding regular police involvement remained unanswered and findings were based on the absence of internal records. The FRO emphasizes the need for thorough, independent investigations into fundamental rights violations.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office concludes as likely that a group of ten migrants was apprehended by the Serbian police in Serbia, transported from the reception centre to the border with Bulgaria, and subsequently forced to cross the border.

location_details: A group of ten migrants, after spending two nights in a public park in Belgrade, was directed by police officers towards a reception centre south of Belgrade. On 26/02/2024, they were put into a police van, escorted by police cars, and driven past Dimitrovgrad to a shallow river at the border with Bulgaria. One officer slapped a migrant, and officers allegedly took phones and documents before ordering them to cross the river into Bulgarian territory.
where_clear: Serbia-Bulgaria border area, including Belgrade, a reception center south of Belgrade, Dimitrovgrad, and a shallow river at the border
geocodable_query: Serbia-Bulgaria border near Dimitrovgrad, including Belgrade and a reception center south of Belgrade
context_note: The Office takes note of the conclusion of the internal checks rejecting allegations but regrets that questions related to the alleged involvement of the regular police remained unanswered and the findings are based primarily on the absence of internal records of any wrongdoing.
evidence_quote: The Fundamental Rights Office concludes as likely that a group of ten migrants was apprehended by the Serbian police in Serbia, transported from the reception centre to the border with Bulgaria, and subsequently forced to cross the border.

context_note: Riots and fires broke out at the Vial RIC in Chios, Greece, following the death of a 49-year-old woman. Offices, canteen, cars, tents, and containers (including Frontex containers) were damaged. Refugees engaged in stone fights with Hellenic Police.
evidence_quote: During the night fires broke out in the offices of the Asylum Service, as well as in the canteen of RIC VIAL. Two cars were also set on fire, while the refugees were engaged in a stone fight with HP.

Moreover several tents and containers outside the main building, but also inside the main building, where all the organisations and agencies are located, were damaged and destroyed. location_details: On the morning of 09 March 2022, one Frontex [redacted] assigned to [redacted] witnessed the interception of two migrants that had crossed the border from Belarus to Lithuania. The two migrants were redirected to Belarus by Lithuanian border guards in application of Decision No. 42 of 2 August 2021.
context_note: Two migrants who crossed the border from Belarus to Lithuania were intercepted by Lithuanian border guards, witnessed by Frontex personnel, and subsequently returned to Belarus under Decision No. 42 of 2 August 2021. The report identifies potential fundamental rights violations including inhuman and degrading treatment, collective expulsion, right to asylum, and non-refoulement. The assessment section discusses concerns regarding effective access to asylum procedures, individual vulnerability assessments, and the prohibition of non-refoulement at the Lithuania-Belarus border, concluding that the Lithuanian authorities' practices may not align with international and EU obligations.
evidence_quote: on the morning of 09 March 2022, one Frontex [...] witnessed the interception of two migrants that had crossed the border from Belarus to Lithuania. The two migrants were redirected to Belarus by Lithuanian border guards in application of Decision No. 42 of 2 August 2021.

location_details: A migrant was apprehended by Albanian authorities, taken to a camp, and then brought to the border near Kakavia to be pushed back to Greece. This occurred twice, with movements between Sarande, Gjirokaster, and the Kakavia border area in Albania, and Delvinaki in Greece.

context_note: An interviewed migrant reported being apprehended twice by Albanian authorities, taken to a camp, and then brought to the border near Kakavia to be shown a path back to Greece. Tracking data from the migrant's phone and consistent accounts from other Serious Incident reports support the allegations of Albanian authorities transporting migrants to the border and instructing them to cross irregularly.

However, due to limited information, the Fundamental Rights Office could not conclusively establish the veracity of allegations or whether a fundamental rights violation occurred.

location_details: An irregular migrant was apprehended by Albanian police and brought to a detention center near Kakavia, Albania. On 07/03/2022, he was taken with other migrants by Albanian authorities to a path leading to the Greek side of the border. The migrant had previously crossed into Albania from Ioannina, Greece, on 05/03/2022 in the Kakavia area. The interview regarding the incident took place in Delvinaki, Greece.

context_note: A complaint was filed regarding alleged misconduct by a Frontex SC Officer and an MKD Officer. The officers reportedly accepted 40 euros as a fine without providing a receipt from a citizen who was stopped on a highway. The SC Officer admitted the incident took place but stated the check was conducted by the MKD Officer while he remained in the patrol car.

location_details: Events occurred on 18-19/04/2020, in which the Frontex Surveillance Aircraft intervened while performing a surveillance flight between the Greek and Turkish maritime border near the island of Lesvos. Latitude: 39.4458333333, Longitude: 26.4391666666.
where_clear: Sea area between Greek and Turkish maritime border, near Lesvos island.
location_text_raw: between the Greek and Turkish maritime border near the island of Lesvos.
context_note: Frontex Surveillance Aircraft intervened during a surveillance flight between the Greek and Turkish maritime border near Lesvos. Migrants were reportedly safe on a patrol vessel, then placed back in a rubber boat, put in distress, and left adrift without propulsion in Turkish territorial waters. This incident is suspected to involve an unprocessed return and potential violations of fundamental rights and the principle of non-refoulement. No Frontex asset was directly involved in the Serious Incident itself.
evidence_quote: Based on the initial information it is suspected that the incident has characteristics of a case of an unprocessed return and violation of the principle of non-refoulement. [...] there is a strong believe that presented facts support an allegation of possible violation of Fundamental Rights or international protection obligations such as the principle of non-refoulement.

location_details: Greek Territorial waters, towed towards Turkish Territorial waters, at the Greek-Turkish border.
where_clear: Greek Territorial waters near the Greek-Turkish border, Aegean Sea
location_text_raw: Greek Territorial waters... towards Turkish Territorial waters... at the Greek-Turkish border.
uncertainty_note: The demarcation of the territorial waters of Greece and Turkey hasn't been agreed yet. The Working Group could not conclusively assess the status of the rubber boat's engine or the presence of Turkish Coast Guard vessels at the scene.
context_note: A Frontex Surveillance Aircraft observed an empty rubber boat being towed by a Hellenic Coast Guard vessel towards Turkish Territorial waters. Approximately 20-30 people were on board the Hellenic Coast Guard vessel and were retransferred onto the rubber boat at the Greek-Turkish border. The Hellenic Coast Guard stated the Turkish Coast Guard took over responsibility, but this could not be corroborated.
evidence_quote: In the night of 18 April 2020, a Frontex Surveillance Aircraft observed a rubber boat in Greek Territorial waters. The rubber boat was empty and being towed by a Hellenic Coast Guard vessel towards Turkish Territorial waters. Approximately 20-30 people were on board the Hellenic Coast Guard vessel that was towing the rubber boat. After some time, these people were retransferred onto the rubber boat at the Greek-Turkish border.

context_note: On 19 April 2020, a boat with people was sighted by a Frontex unit in Turkish territorial waters. Turkish authorities were informed, and the Hellenic Coast Guard took measures to address the illegal border crossing, ensuring safety and compliance with international law and European legislation. The situation involved efficient coordination between Greek and Turkish authorities, respecting all parties' rights and considering COVID-19 related health risks for preventing unauthorized border crossings.
evidence_quote: As regards the circumstances of the event that took place on 19 April 2020, please be informed on the followings: These circumstances involved a boat carrying a number of people which was first sighted by a Frontex participating unit in Turkish territorial waters.

location_details: The boat was first sighted in Turkish territorial waters in the Eastern Aegean Sea. The incident involved coordination between Greek and Turkish authorities.
where_clear: Eastern Aegean Sea, Turkish territorial waters
geocodable_query: Eastern Aegean Sea, Turkish territorial waters
context_note: A Frontex surveillance aircraft sighted an incident in the Eastern Aegean. A Hellenic Coast Guard (HCG) patrol boat, not co-financed by Frontex, was involved. The HCG stated the boat was first sighted in Turkish territorial waters. Migrants were initially safe on the Greek patrol boat but were later placed back in a rubber boat, left adrift without propulsion, leading to a distress situation. This sequence of events indicates a strong possibility of fundamental rights violations and non-refoulement. HCG will be requested to conduct an internal investigation.
evidence_quote: There is a strong indication that these facts could support an allegation of possible violation of Fundamental Rights or international protection obligations such as the principle of non-refoulement.

location_details: The incident occurred in the Eastern Aegean Sea, specifically in Turkish territorial waters, involving a Greek Coast Guard patrol boat and a rubber boat with migrants.
where_clear: Eastern Aegean Sea, Turkish territorial waters
geocodable_query: Eastern Aegean Sea, Turkish territorial waters
context_note: A Frontex surveillance aircraft sighted an incident involving a Hellenic Coast Guard (HCG) patrol boat and a rubber boat with migrants in Turkish territorial waters in the Eastern Aegean. The HCG stated they took appropriate measures to address illegal border crossing and ensured the safety of migrants, coordinating with Turkish authorities to end the situation. However, the SIR Coordinator assessed that migrants, initially safe on the Greek patrol boat, were later left in a distress situation in a rubber boat without propulsion. The HCG patrol boat and assets were not co-financed by Frontex nor part of JO Poseidon 2020 or RBI Aegean 2020. A Sea Border Expert from ICC Piraeus, a Hellenic Coast Guard Officer, was giving instructions due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. HCG will be requested to conduct an internal investigation.
evidence_quote: There is a strong indication that these facts could support an allegation of possible violation of Fundamental Rights or international protection obligations such as the principle of non-refoulement.

location_details: Four migrants were apprehended by Frontex and Lithuanian border guards after crossing from Belarus to Lithuania, and subsequently redirected to Belarus.
context_note: Lithuanian authorities explain that Decision No. 42 of 2 August 2021, adopted under a state-level emergency, restricts entry to functioning international border crossing points. The FRO observes that while Article 15 ECHR allows derogations, it does not justify denying effective access to asylum or non-refoulement. Access to designated points appears neither genuine nor effective in practice, and no individual vulnerability assessment was conducted before returning migrants to Belarus, despite reports of mistreatment by Belarusian authorities. The FRO recommends administrative closure but notes the events may amount to serious breaches of fundamental rights.
evidence_quote: On 13 March, four Afghans migrants apprehended were returned to Belarus in application of Decision No. 42 of 2 August 2021

location_details: Incident occurred near the Albanian-Greek border. The migrant was apprehended by Albanian police, transferred to a detention center in the vicinity of a redacted location, then transported to a location with a small wooden bridge and a monastery nearby, before being directed towards the Greek border. The Office corroborated the existence of an abandoned bridge and a monastery close-by in the estimated area.
where_clear: Albanian-Greek border area, involving a detention center in Albania.
location_text_raw: Greek-Albanian border on foot in the area of [REDACTED]
uncertainty_note: Significant redactions and vague descriptions like 'vicinity of', 'nearby', 'closer to the Greek border', and 'estimated location' prevent precise geocoding. While an abandoned bridge and monastery were corroborated, their specific locations are redacted.
context_note: The Fundamental Rights Office received information from Frontex operational staff about a migrant who alleged being apprehended by Albanian police on 15/03/2023. The migrant and their group were allegedly transferred to a detention center, photographed, and later transported to the Greek border. The Albanian authorities denied the collective expulsion, stating that the group was interviewed, photographed, fingerprinted, and issued an Order of Voluntary Removal on 13.03.2023, then 'left free in the territory of Albania'. The FRO notes discrepancies in dates and locations but finds the migrant's account relatively credible, consistent with previous SIRs regarding irregular returns by Albanian officers to Greece. The FRO concludes it is possible the group was irregularly returned to Greece by Albanian officers.
evidence_quote: Based on the available information the Fundamental Rights Office finds it possible that the group of migrants in the case under scrutiny was irregularly returned to Greece by Albanian officers.

location_details: A migrant alleged being apprehended by Albanian police on 15/03/2023. After apprehension, he and his group were transferred to a detention center in the vicinity of [REDACTED]. They spent a few hours there, received food and water, and were photographed but not fingerprinted. Later, Albanian officers transported them to a location with a small wooden bridge and a monastery nearby. From this location, they continued on foot for approximately 10 minutes. When closer to the Greek border, Albanian officers returned personal belongings and showed them the direction to proceed towards Greece. The incident occurred after crossing the Greek-Albanian border on foot in the area of [REDACTED].
where_clear: Greek-Albanian border area, near a detention center, small wooden bridge and monastery
location_text_raw: Greek-Albanian border on foot in the area of [REDACTED], a detention center in the vicinity of [REDACTED] (location identified by the migrant as: [REDACTED]), a location with a small wooden bridge and a monastery nearby (estimated location according to the migrant: [REDACTED])
uncertainty_note: Specific locations are redacted, making precise geocoding impossible.
context_note: The Office remains concerned about such practice and underlines that similar allegations had been raised in the framework of SIRs several times.
evidence_quote: Based on the available information the Fundamental Rights Office finds it possible that the group of migrants in the case under scrutiny was irregularly returned to Greece by Albanian officers.

context_note: A migrant reported being part of a group (29-30 individuals) pushed back to Türkiye from near Samos Island on 15 September 2022, after being sexually assaulted by masked men. The Fundamental Rights Office considers the pushback credible and plausible, potentially involving the Hellenic Coast Guard. While unable to independently corroborate the sexual violence and perpetrator identity, the allegations are deemed relatively credible.

The burglars stole tablets, the pilots' licences, the logbook, a passport, headphones, the keys of the [redacted] and other personal items belonging to the crew.
